project_goals.title: Crew-7 Overall Vision
project_goals.copilot_prompt:
Project context: This repository implements Crew-7, a multi-agent AI platform where structured crews of 7 agents (1 Orchestrator + 6 specialists) can design, build, and maintain software systems.

High-level goals:
1) Users can pick a prebuilt crew (e.g., Backend Builder, Frontend Builder) or create their own crew.
2) A run executes the crew (powered by CrewAI + LLMs) to produce real artifacts (e.g., FastAPI scaffolds, Next.js UIs, tests) using a secure tool sandbox.
3) The UI has a normal Chat mode and an Advanced Mode with a visual agent graph, showing which agents are active and how they communicate.
4) The platform is safe (resource-limited tools), multi-tenant (org/workspace aware), and observable (traces, metrics, logs).
5) There is a small marketplace of prebuilt crews that can be installed into a workspace.

When editing any code in this repo, keep these constraints in mind:
- Do not turn this app into a generic chat assistant. It must stay centered on multi-agent crews and building real projects.
- Prefer structured APIs (crews, runs, tools, traces, marketplace) over one-off ad-hoc endpoints.
- Preserve existing types and endpoints where possible; make changes additive and backwards compatible.

Your task whenever this prompt is present: before implementing any feature or refactor, check if it supports or conflicts with this vision. If it conflicts, suggest a design that stays aligned with Crew-7's goals instead.

project_goals.title: Backend Scope & Boundaries
project_goals.copilot_prompt:
Backend scope reminder for Crew-7.

What the backend MUST do:
1) Provide REST + SSE + WebSocket APIs to manage users, orgs, crews, runs, traces, tools, and marketplace templates.
2) Use CrewAI (or similar) as the multi-agent engine, with per-crew memory and secure tool execution via Docker sandbox.
3) Expose tools such as git clone, pytest, bash script, and GitHub PR creation in a controlled, resource-limited way.
4) Persist run lifecycle (queued, running, succeeded, failed), events (agent_start, agent_end, tool calls), and artifacts.
5) Support a minimal billing model (credits per run) and basic LLM connection management (per-org API keys/models).

What the backend MUST NOT do:
- No heavy UI logic or templating; all presentation lives in the frontend.
- No storing raw secrets in plain text; secrets must be sealed/encrypted and only exposed in masked form.
- No long-running unbounded processes; everything must be time-limited and safe for multi-tenant use.

When making backend changes, ensure new endpoints and services:
- Fit the nouns: crew, run, tool, trace, env var, llm connection, template.
- Are idempotent where possible, and do not break existing clients.
- Are safe by default (limited CPU/RAM, restricted filesystem, no unexpected network access).

project_goals.title: Frontend Scope & UX Pillars
project_goals.copilot_prompt:
Frontend scope reminder for Crew-7.

UX pillars:
1) Simple default: a chat-first interface where a user can select a crew, type a goal, and see streaming progress.
2) Power mode: an Advanced Mode that reveals an agent graph, traces, and configuration for advanced users.
3) Fast onboarding: guest or quick sign-up should land on a dashboard where a user can run a prebuilt crew in under 60 seconds.
4) Consistent visual language: dark theme, neon accents, robot avatars for agents, clear status indicators (available, running, failed).

Core pages/components:
- Dashboard: quick stats + quick actions (Backend Scaffold, Frontend Scaffold).
- Chat / Command feed: streaming run output, controls to restart/modify prompt.
- Advanced Mode (AgentGraph): XYFlow-based graph of agents and edges, with pause/resume/cancel and basic editing.
- Marketplace: browse/install prebuilt crews.
- Mission Lab: Traces, LLM Connections, Environment Variables.
- Settings: Account, Organization, Billing, Security, Integrations, Notifications.

When editing frontend code:
- Do not add random pages or flows that are not about crews, runs, or their configuration.
- Prefer composing existing components (cards, badges, avatars, graph) over introducing new design systems.
- Always think: will this help a user run a crew successfully and understand what happened?

project_goals.title: Advanced Mode & Agent Graph Goals
project_goals.copilot_prompt:
Advanced Mode / Agent Graph scope reminder.

Goals:
1) When no run is active, show only the chat view; the AgentGraph should be hidden or minimized.
2) When a run is active, Advanced Mode can be toggled on: the chat shrinks, and an interactive graph shows all agents and their connections.
3) The graph is not just decorative: it should react to live events from the backend (agent_start, agent_end, edge(message)) and visually highlight activity.
4) Power users can pause, resume, or cancel the run, adjust the graph layout, and eventually tweak prompts/tools per node.

Constraints:
- The AgentGraph is read-only for the current run except for control actions (pause/resume/cancel); structural edits should be persisted as crew configuration, not just transient graph state.
- Do not block or slow down the main chat when Advanced Mode is enabled.
- Keep the graph implementation aligned with XYFlow/ReactFlow best practices and Crew-7 styling (robot avatars, neon lines).

Whenever modifying the AgentGraph or Advanced Mode logic, ensure it remains a helpful, live visualization of crew behavior and not a separate, unrelated feature.

project_goals.title: Marketplace & Templates Goals
project_goals.copilot_prompt:
Marketplace scope reminder.

Goals:
1) Provide a small but high-impact set of prebuilt crews (e.g., Backend Builder, Frontend Builder, Simple ETL) that users can install into their workspace.
2) Installing a template should create a configured crew that can run immediately with minimal setup.
3) Marketplace items should be described in a way that is understandable for non-experts (what the crew does, inputs, outputs).

Constraints:
- Marketplace is about reusable crew definitions and configurations, not arbitrary code snippets.
- Installing a template should never overwrite or delete existing user crews.
- All marketplace crews must respect the same safety and sandbox rules as user-defined crews.

When adding or editing marketplace-related code, make sure templates are treated as first-class crews and kept simple enough for an MVP.
